Rich - 

Interesting to see this tsuba. My Akasaka of this design signed Ta=
dashige (to my relief) passed shinsa in Chicago. Of course I have it here i=
n front of me now to compare the work with your tsuba. While the design is =
the same, the work on mine is more delicate (?)--more piercing--and seems t=
o "flow" more, if you know what I mean. The horse's hoofs on your tsuba are=
 more "squared" and "bold" than the more naturally shaped hoofs on my tsuba=
. I just saw a similar tsuba (picture) just the other day that showed these=
 rather boldly made hoofs and it was called something other than Akasaka, b=
ut for the life of me I don't recall where I saw this. Thought it was in th=
e new Mosle' catalogue, but if so, I'm not finding it now. My tsuba came ou=
t of a large collection of tsuba sold in Santiago, Chile in 2003. That coll=
ection also had another similar "horse" tsuba that had these large hoofs li=
ke your new tsuba, but I didn't buy that one. Most of these 730-plus tsuba =
were bought up by Michael Zomber, so perhaps your's could be the one I saw.=
 I'll check my records. 

Ron
STL
